snippet: It is the vividness of a perceived threat, rather than the threat’s true potency, that plays the bigger role in the potential to spread through social media, researchers find.
abstract: Researchers say people tend to share stories that stir their deepest feelings on social media, which is why Ebola is trending on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: It is the vividness of a perceived threat, rather than the threat’s true potency, that plays the bigger role in the potential to spread through social media, researchers find.

headline.main: Ebola May Pose Little Threat to U.S., but It Looms Large on Twitter
